title: Localization of “climate talk” and “storm talk” in Feb 2014, France.
sections:
Localization of “climate talk” and “storm talk” in Feb 2014, France.

The map shows the geographical distribution of thematised user comments on Facebook in response to posts [what posts?] by national and local French newspapers. The map demonstrates the perentage of total comments made in Februrary 2014 (when a series of violent storms hit the Atlantic coast) which refer to ‘storm talk’ (comments focusing on current weather events) and ‘climate talk’ (comments focusing on climate and climate change).  The 9 national newspapers used are, by definition, distributed nationally. In contrast, whilst the 14 local newspapers reach various audiences across various regions in France, it was beyond the scope of the investigation to cover every department.

Figure 1. A geographical illustration of the percentage of total Facebook comments made on national and local French newspaper pages in Feb 2014 which refer to ‘stormtalk’ and ‘climatetalk’. SOURCE: DATE: 28 March 2014

How to read the map

The darker the shaded area, the higher the percentage of total comments which refer to ‘storm’ or ‘climate’ talk. The red areas demonstrate predominantely ‘climate related comments’  whilst the blue areas represent predominantely ‘storm related comments’.

These Facebook pages were scraped using the Netvizz application. Subsequently, using the Comment Analysis tool, we were able to analyse the content of the comments. To be able to make several different comparisons, the files were put through the tool individually, as well as grouped by year as a total, and grouped by year and reach (national or local). After manually reading through comments and testing queries for their effectiveness, we decided on the following queries as the basis of our research:

  • [tempete]
  • [climat OR rechauffement]

While the French terms tempête and réchauffement use accents, the tool was programmed to recognise the spelling with and without accents. The query ‘climat’ will, in this tool, also return longer words such as climatique. The first query is often used to refer to storms, and will thus create strong links with the weather events at hand at a certain time. We coined the term ‘stormtalk’ for the conversations captured by this query. The second query is designed to return comments on climate and climate change, referred to in this project as ‘climatetalk’.

In order to locate the comments geographically we looked at the departments in which the newspapers are distributed and grouped them according to this. Using the Comment Analysis tool, the percentages of ‘stormtalk’ and ‘climatetalk’ of each researched month were calculated separately.
